content.question: Spheres <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> are put briefly into contact. Which of the following best explains the resulting charge on spheres <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>B</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>?

choices.label: A charge that is equal in magnitude and sign to the charge on sphere <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> will be attracted onto sphere <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>B</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, so both spheres will have a charge of <math alttext="positive 10 nanocoulombs " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mo>+</mo><mn>10</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>n</mi><mi>C</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.

A charge that is equal in magnitude and opposite in sign to the charge on sphere <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> will be attracted onto sphere <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>B</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, so sphere <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> will still have a charge of <math alttext="positive 10 nanocoulombs" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mo>+</mo><mn>10</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>n</mi><mi>C</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and sphere <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>B</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> will have a charge of <math alttext="negative 10 nanocoulombs" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>10</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>n</mi><mi>C</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.

The net charge on identical conductors is shared equally when they are put into contact, so both spheres will have a charge of <math alttext="positive 5 nanocoulombs" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mo>+</mo><mn>5</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>n</mi><mi>C</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.

Before sphere <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and sphere <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>B</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> are brought into contact, sphere <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> will polarize sphere <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>B</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, resulting in a net charge of <math alttext="negative 5 nanocoulombs" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>n</mi><mi>C</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> on the near side of sphere <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>B</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="positive 5 nanocoulombs" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mo>+</mo><mn>5</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>n</mi><mi>C</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> on the far side of sphere <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>B</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. When sphere <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and sphere B are in contact, the charge <math alttext="negative 5 nanocoulombs" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>n</mi><mi>C</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> on the near side of sphere <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>B</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> will move onto sphere <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, resulting in sphere <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> having a net charge of <math alttext="positive 5 nanocoulombs" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mo>+</mo><mn>5</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>n</mi><mi>C</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and sphere <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>B</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> having a net charge of <math alttext="negative 5 nanocoulombs" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>n</mi><mi>C</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.
